item.title: NASA Spent Six Hundred Thousand Dollars and Never Ran the Test. The Inventor Won't Tell You Why.
item.description: In the early 1990s, a Russian materials scientist at Tampere University of Technology in Finland claimed that a rotating superconducting ceramic disk reduced the weight of objects placed above it by somewhere between 0.05 and 0.5 percent. His name was Evgeny Podkletnov. The claim was specific, the mechanism was unspecified, the effect was small enough that it might have been measurement error, and nobody in mainstream physics had a theoretical framework that would predict anything like it.
